Situation1: They are asked to take part in an important family event like a holiday celebration or trip.
Expectation2: Offer help or support when asked
Situation2: An acquaintance asks for assistance in moving a few boxes while moving to a new apartment.
Story: I stared at my phone, rereading the messages. My stepmom had just texted, reminding me about the family holiday dinner this Saturday. “It would mean a lot if you could be there,” she wrote, and I could almost hear her hopeful tone. Ever since Dad remarried, I’d tried to show up for these things, to be a good step-sibling, to make the family feel whole. But then, another message popped up—this one from Jamie, a classmate I barely knew outside of group projects. “Hey, sorry for the last-minute ask, but could you help me move some boxes Saturday afternoon? I’m really stuck.” I knew Jamie didn’t have many friends in town, and I’d always tried to be the kind of person who helped when asked. My stomach twisted. If I said yes to Jamie, I’d miss the family dinner and probably disappoint my step-siblings, who were finally starting to warm up to me. But if I said no, I’d be letting down someone who genuinely needed help. I sat there, phone in hand, feeling the weight of both expectations pressing in, unsure which part of me I was supposed to honor.
